gurmukhi: iSv qy jnu gMg qrMg Cuty ] ieh huie jn jog jtw pRgty ] qp srb qpISn ky sB hI ] mun jy sB CIn ley qbhI ]377]
transliteration: Shiv Te Jan(u) Gadg Taran Chhoute|| Eh Hue Jan Jog Jataa Pragte|| Tap Sarab Tapeeshan Ke Sabh Hee|| Mounndje Sabh Chin Lae Tab-hee||377||
translation: Their Yogic matted locks waved like the waves of the Ganges emanating from Shiva; they performed various kinds of austerities following the practices of earlier ascetics.377.

gurmukhi: sRuq jyiqk nXws audws khy ] sBhI irK AMgn jwn ley ] Gn mY ijm ib`dulqw JmkY ] irK mo gn qws sBY dmkY ]378]
transliteration: Srout Jetik Nuaas Udaas Kage|| Sabh-hirikh Anad Jaan Lae|| Ghan Mai Jim Biddulataa Jhamkai|| Rikh Mo Gad Taas Sobhai Damkai||378||
translation: All the various practices which have been described in Shrutis (Vedas), they were all performed by these sages; all the qualities of these sages flashed like lightning amongst the clouds.378.

gurmukhi: js Cwfq Bwn AnMq Ctw ] irK ky iqm soBq jog jtw ] ijnkI duK PwNs khUM n ktI ] irK Bytq qws Ctwk CutI ]379]
transliteration: Jas Chhadat Bhaan Anant Chhataa|| Rikh Ke Tim Sobhat Jog Jataa|| Jinkidoukh Phaans Kahoon Na Katee|| Rikh Bhetat Taas Chhataak Chhoutee||379||
translation: The matted locks waved on the heads of the Yogis like the rays coming out of the sun; those whose suffering ended on seeing these sges.379.

gurmukhi: nr jo nhI nrkn qy invrY ] irK Bytq qaun qrwk qrY ] ijn ky smqw khUM mwih TtI ] irK pUj GtI sB pwp GtI ]380]
transliteration: Nar Jo Nahinarkan Te Nidarai|| Rikh Bhetat Taoun Taraak Darai|| Jin Ke Samtaa Kahoon Maah(i) Thatee|| Rikh Pooj Ghatisabh Paap Ghatee||380||
translation: Those men and women, who had been cast in hell, they were redeemed on seeing these sages; those who had any sin within them, their sinful life endeed on worshipping these sages.380.

gurmukhi: ieq bMDp qaun ibTo miRghw ] js hyrq Cyirin BI iBfhw ] iqh jwn irKI nhI sws ssXo ] miRg jwn munI khu bwn kmXo ]381]
transliteration: It Bandhap Taoun Bitho Mrigadaa|| Jas Heart Chherin(i) Bhibhid-haa|| Tih Jaan Rikhinahisaas Sasyo|| Mrig Jaan Mounndkaoub Baan Kasyo||381||
translation: On this side, this hunter was sitting, on seeing whom, the animals used to run away; he did not recognize the sage and condidering him a deer, he aimed his arrow at him.381.

gurmukhi: sr pyK sBY iqh swDk hY ] miRg hoie nry muin rwj iehY ] nr bwn srwsn pwn qjy ] As dyK diRVM mun rwj ljy ]382]
transliteration: Sar Pekh Sabhai Tih Saadhak Hai|| Mrig Hoe Dare Mounndi) Raaj Ihai|| Nar Baan Saraasan Paan Taje|| As Dekh Dridan Mounndraaj Laje||382||
translation: All the ascetics saw the arrow and also saw that the sage was seated like a deer; that person his bow and arrows from his hand and felt ashamed on seeing the resoluteness of the sage.382.

gurmukhi: bhuqy icr ijau iqh DXwn Cutw ] Aivloik Dry irKpwl jtw ] ks Awvq ho fr fwr AbY ] muih lwgq ho miRg rUp sbY ]383]
transliteration: Bahoute Chir Jio Tih Dhyaan Chhoutaa|| Anilok(i) Ddare Rikhpaal Jataa|| Kas Aavat Ho Dar Daar Abai|| Muh(i) Laagad Ho Mrig Roop Sabai||383||
translation: After a long time, when his attention was broken, then he saw the great sage with matted locks; he said. “How al of you have come here after relinquishing your fear? I am seeing only the deer everywhere.”383.

gurmukhi: irKpwl iblok iqsY idVqw ] gur mwn krI bhuqY aupmw ] miRg so ijh ko icq AYs lgXo ] prmySr ky rs jwn pgXo ]384]
transliteration: Rikhpaal Bilok Tisai Dridraa|| Gur Maan Karibahoutai Oupmaa|| Mrig So Jih Ko Chit Ais Lagyo|| Parmeshar Ke Ras Jaan Pagyo||384||
translation: The sage, seeing his resoluteness, and accepting him as his Guru, praised him and said, “He, who is so much attentive towards the deer, then think that he is absorbed in the love of the Lord.”384.

gurmukhi: mun ko qb pRym pRsIj hIAw ] gur Twrsmo miRghw su kIAw ] mn mo qb d`q bIcwr kIAw ] gun miRghw ko icq bIc lIAw ]385]
transliteration: Mounndko Tab Prem Praseej Heeaa|| Gru Thaarasmo Mrigadaa Su Keeaa|| Man Mo Tab Datt Beechaar Keeaa|| Goun Mrigadaa Ko Chit Beech Leeaa||385||
translation: The sage accepted him as his eighteenth Guru with his melted heart; the sage Dutt thoughtfully adopted the qualities of that hunter in his mind.385.

gurmukhi: hir soihq jo ieh BwNiq krY ] Bv Bwr Apwrh pwr prY ] ml AMqir Xwih Snwn ktY ] jg qy iPr Awvn jwn imtY ]386]
transliteration: Har(i) Sohit Jo Eh Bhaant(i) Darai|| Bhav Bhaar Apaarah Paar Darai|| Mal Antar(i) Yaah(i) Shanaan Katai|| Jag Te Phir Aavan Jaan Mitai||386||
translation: He, who will love the Lord in this way, he will ferry across the ocean of existence; his dirt will be removed with the inner bath and his transmigration will end in the world.386.

gurmukhi: gur jwn qby iqh pwie prw ] Bv pwr Apwr su pwr qrw ] ds Astsmo gur qws kIXo ] kib bwNiD kib`qn m`iD lIXo ]387]
transliteration: Gur Jaan Tabe Tih Paae Paraa|| Bhav Paar Apaar Su Paar Taraa|| Das Astasmo Gur Taas Keeyo|| Kabi Baandh(i) Kabittan Maddh Leeyo||387||
translation: Accepting him as his Guru, he fell at his feet and ferried across the dreadful ocean of existence; he adopted him as his eighteenth Guru and in tthis way, the poet has mentioned the save in verse-form.387.

gurmukhi: sB hI isK sMjuiq pwn ghy ] Aivlok crwcir cauD rhy ] psu p`C crwcr jIv sBY ] gx gMDRb BUq ipswc qbY ]388]
transliteration: Sabh Hisikh Sanjout(i) Paan Gade|| Avilok Charaachar(i) Chaudh Rahe|| Pas(i) Pachchh Charaachar Jeev Sabhai|| Gad Gaddhrab Bhoot Pisaach Tabai||388||
translation: All the disciples gathered and caught his feet, seeing which all the animate and inanimate beings were startled; all the animals, birds, gandharvas, ghosts, fiends etc. were wonder-struck.388.
End of the description of the adoption of a Hunter as the Eighteenth Guru.
